Patch Set 15:

(1 comment)
Could you point me to where the overflow happens?

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/fdd26906ef8884977df85c915444206c8a183639/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1204

Here, having any non-zero skip with top not provided overflows
That's a really good point, I missed that.  hmm.... that makes me wonder if we need a way to have an "unspecified" value.

Yes but previously it's the same behavior. bmcweb itself limits GET request to LogService return at most 1000 logs at once. Previously this limit is only checked when top is specified.

See my comment on that part.

Understood.

Is it possible that we fix the actual bug. I would imagine we use std::optional for these two query parameters and check they are set or not before using?
Even use std::optional, these parameter still need to have a default value, and the default value of $top cannot be UINT32_MAX

> Is it possible that we fix the actual bug. I would imagine we use std::optional for these two query parameters and check they are set or not before using?

That seems reasonable.


> Even use std::optional, these parameter still need to have a default value

Why?  std::optional would mean it doesn't need a default int value.  The default value would be std::nullopt

I think there need to be a default value for $top which limits how much log entries are responded in single request. Currently that default value is 1000. If std::nullopt means "get all logs at once", and there are lots of log entries on system, it will result in an denial of service in bmcweb.

> I think there need to be a default value for $top which limits how much log entries are responded in single request. 

Why?  In the current version of the code, it actually generates as many entries as the collection allows anyway, so setting a default limit doesn't actually save any memory (it does make the return size smaller).  Is there a case where a log service would return more than the default number of logs (1000) but not delegate the top/skip calls to efficient routes?

> Why?  In the current version of the code, it actually generates as many entries as the collection allows anyway, so setting a default limit doesn't actually save any memory 

I rechecked the code implementation, that's right. I will use std::optional<size_t> for $top, when the value is not given, return all logs. But $skip will keep using size_t as its default should be 0.

> Is there a case where a log service would return more than the default number of logs (1000) but not delegate the top/skip calls to efficient routes?

There is no such cases
Done
Is 1000 consistent across the Redfish tree?
nit: I prefer inline constexpr.

Yes all $top are checked in getTopParam()

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/b66cf2a2f10aab3bd21e8be60b7fb0894d342c05/redfish-core/include/utils/query_param.hpp#L186
`static constexpr` is widely used in bmcweb, while `inline constexpr` not, and this line is moved from previous file. I prefer keep it here.

Arguably this would normally be "constexpr const size_t"

For const parameters, it's not clear the difference is all that important.  Up to the submitter if they want to change it.
This is likely something we'll need to evolve over time, but 1000 as a default seems resonable.

https://abseil.io/tips/168

Please see this.
Ack

Done. Changed to "inline constexpr"

Thanks Nan for the information
this should be <=
Done

I'd also like to ask if this test case is correct. In the TopNegative case above, canDelegateTop is also initialized to false by default. The result of this case is the same. Maybe here canDelegateTop should be true?

Wait, this test is actually wrong.

Please see https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/54933.

Thanks for finding it.
Oh, you already have a fix. Abandon mine.

And previously (without this oveflow bug from commit c937d2bfefa3ff91b7175d9684f99712ec9b88e5) also initializes the max allowed $top to 1000

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/5e52870bbadc7e35ff47325ffa668a6b82bf9c4a/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1208
Changed to std::nullopt

Previously the 1000-limit is here. If top is specified to any number >1000, it returns an here. If it is unspecified, SIZE_T_MAX is used and overflow happens. I just makes the 1000-limit more global I think.
Changed to std::nullopt
Can we also get the NextLink tested in event log?
Done
wait, can we really hit this branch now?
Yes this will never be reached, removed.
?  I'm pretty sure we still want to impose reasonable limits here;  Setting this to size_t max would mean it's likely we can run out of memory.
Done by put the previous 1000-entry limit back.
Not using std::optional any more so that this is no longer a problem

Can you please break up this logic a little?  It was difficult to read before, now it's really tough.

Also, as written, this change the default max size from being 10000 to size_t::max, which I'm pretty sure isn't what we want.

> this change the default max size from being 10000 to size_t::max, which I'm pretty sure isn't what we want.

Why do we have 10000 in the first place?
Because if you have a resource that has 1 million items, you don't want to run the bmc out of resources trying to generate the json representation of it.

Before coding, I'd like to discuss something.

Previously the limit is 1000 entries per GET request, any $top value larger than 1000 will be rejected. What should the new behavior be?

1. Keep old behavior, then the std::optional here is pretty useless as the default value can simply be 1000, and it rarely overflow.
2. Let any value to be specified, but by default it would be 1000. I personally prefer this one, but users must ensure their query will not crash the BMC.

> Before coding, I'd like to discuss something.
> 
> Previously the limit is 1000 entries per GET request, any $top value larger than 1000 will be rejected. What should the new behavior be?
> 
> 1. Keep old behavior, then the std::optional here is pretty useless as the default value can simply be 1000, and it rarely overflow.

I think this is the answer.

> 2. Let any value to be specified, but by default it would be 1000. I personally prefer this one, but users must ensure their query will not crash the BMC.

This one is a non starter.  Users are also potential attackers, and there's no way for a user to know what queries will and wont run the bmc out of resources.  We need some kind of limit here.
Making the default value being 1000 no longer needs using the std::optional as $top now always has a value. Changed back to my initial patch.
LGTM.  Need to make sure Nans questions are answered sufficiently to his liking, the I think this can go.

nit.  Feel free to ignore, because this code is still better than before, but would this parameter make more sense to put in the Query struct directly next to the top parameter?  That way it's a lot more clear what its intended use is?
If we want to do this, lets do it in another patch.
I was not working when you reviews this patch. I've submitted another patch at https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/55574 for the requested change.
shall we check if $top is in the range of [0, 1000] in |queryParameterValueFormatError| now?
I think it's already covered.  See check below.
Ack
@Nan, we already check the range here.
